Basic package workflow

Source: vignettes/steppedwedge.Rmd
steppedwedge.Rmd
library(steppedwedge)

The load_data function takes in raw data and creates a data object that can be accepted by the plot_design and analyze functions. We use the made-up dataframe sw_data_example to demonstrate the workflow.

data(sw_data_example)
head(sw_data_example)
#>   cluster period trt      prob outcome_bin outcome_cont
#> 1       1      1   0 0.2687284           1  -1.05306411
#> 2       1      1   0 0.2687284           1  -0.02333027
#> 3       1      1   0 0.2687284           0   0.44821454
#> 4       1      1   0 0.2687284           0   0.94435983
#> 5       1      1   0 0.2687284           0  -0.48427045
#> 6       1      1   0 0.2687284           0   0.30641843

dat <- load_data(
  time = "period",
  cluster_id = "cluster",
  individual_id = NULL,
  treatment = "trt",
  outcome = "outcome_bin",
  data = sw_data_example
)
#> Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) : 
#>   object 'type_sum.accel' not found
#> Stepped wedge dataset loaded. Discrete time design with 15 clusters, 5 sequences, and 6 time points. 0/2011 rows were dropped due to missing values for `cluster_id`, `time`, `treatment`, or `outcome`.

The plot_design function produces a diagram of the stepped wedge design and a summary of the variables.

plot_dat <- plot_design(dat)

print(plot_dat)
#> $design_plot

The analyze function analyzes the stepped wedge data. First, we analyze the data using a mixed effects model, with the Time Average Treament Effect (TATE) as the estimand, assuming an Immediate Treatment (IT) effect, passing the family = "binomial" and link = "logit" arguments to glmer.

analysis_1 <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "mixed",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "IT",
  family = binomial,
  re = c("clust", "time")
)

print(analysis_1)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.104
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.54, 0.749
#> Converged: TRUE

Repeat the analysis, but including a random effect for cluster only, not for cluster-time interaction.

analysis_1b <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "mixed",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "IT",
  family = binomial,
  re = "clust"
)

print(analysis_1b)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.189
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.19, 0.567
#> Converged: TRUE

Repeat the analysis, but using GEE rather than a mixed model.

analysis_2 <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "GEE",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "IT",
  family = binomial,
  corstr = "exchangeable"
)

print(analysis_2)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.176
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.286, 0.638
#> Converged:

Mixed model, with Time Average Treament Effect (TATE) as the estimand, using an Exposure Time Indicator (ETI) model.

analysis_3 <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "mixed",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "ETI",
  family = binomial
)

print(analysis_3)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.146
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.827, 1.118
#> Converged: TRUE

Mixed model, with Time Average Treatment Effect (TATE) as the estimand, using a Natural Cubic Splines (NCS) model.

analysis_4 <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "mixed",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "NCS",
  family = binomial
)
#> Warning in checkConv(attr(opt, "derivs"), opt$par, ctrl = control$checkConv, :
#> Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.00438029 (tol = 0.002, component 1)

print(analysis_4)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.119
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.846, 1.084
#> Converged: FALSE

Mixed model, with Time Average Treament Effect (TATE) as the estimand, using a Treatment Effect Heterogeneity over exposure time (TEH) model.

analysis_5 <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "mixed",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "TEH",
  family = binomial
)
#> boundary (singular) fit: see help('isSingular')

print(analysis_5)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.104
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.541, 0.749
#> Converged: TRUE

Continuous outcome

Mixed model, with Time Average Treament Effect (TATE) as the estimand, using a Natural Cubic Splines (NCS) model.

analysis_6 <- analyze(
  dat = dat,
  method = "mixed",
  estimand = "TATE", 
  exp_time = "NCS",
  family = gaussian
)

print(analysis_6)
#> Treatment effect estimate: 0.01
#> Treatment effect 95% confidence interval: -0.128, 0.149
#> Converged: TRUE
